thread.title: Horrified witnesses describe moment woman killed outside Starbucks in Storm Doris was 'nearly decapitated' by flying debris
thread.title_full: Horrified witnesses describe moment woman killed outside Starbucks in Storm Doris was 'nearly decapitated' by flying debris

author: Lucy Clarke-Billings
title: Horrified witnesses describe moment woman killed outside Starbucks in Storm Doris was 'nearly decapitated' by flying debris
text:
News Horrified witnesses describe moment woman killed outside Starbucks in Storm Doris was 'nearly decapitated' by flying debris Shocked onlookers said they saw 'blood everywhere' when a piece of wood 'the size of a coffee table' crashed into the woman in a busy shopping area Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Woman killed by 'Storm Doris debris' in Wolverhampton Share this video Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Horrified witnesses have described the moment a woman was "near-decapitated" by falling debris outside a Starbucks during 90mph Storm Doris winds. 
Emergency services were called to Wolverhampton at 11.43am following reports of a serious incident outside the coffee shop in the town centre's Dudley Street. 
West Midlands Ambulance Service confirmed a piece of debris fell onto the street leading to 15 999 calls. 
Eyewitnesses say the victim appeared to be a young woman in her 20s and she was drinking outside the coffee shop at the time of the incident. Read More Storm Doris: Live updates as one woman killed and more injured as 100mph winds cause traffic chaos The incident happened as fierce winds battered Britain (Photo: Caters News Agency) 
Kitty Jenkins, 38, a Holland and Barrett shop worker, said: "I was out on my lunch hour when it happened. 
"A piece of debris from the roof just came down and hit her. She went down straight away. 
"There was blood everywhere.." A woman has been killed after debris fell onto the high street outside a Starbucks in Wolverhampton (Photo: Caters News Agency) 
Witnesses said the area was busy with shoppers at the time and some commuters were seen in tears following the tragedy. 
It comes after a series of incidents across the UK this afternoon following strong winds caused by Storm Doris. Read More 
A 19-year-old student, who did not want to be named, added: "My friend saw what happened and had to go home this afternoon, she was in pieces. 
"She said the poor girl was near-decapitated. It's absolutely horrendous." 
Rebecca Davis, a 40-year-old teacher from Wolverhampton, walked past Starbucks shortly after the incident and saw a woman receiving CPR. 
She said the woman appeared to have been hit by something resembling a piece of roof which had fallen off a building nearby. A police officer at the scene in Wolverhampton (Photo: Caters News Agency) 
"I think the wind broke it and caused it to fall. I don't know if it was hit by something else or just the wind did it," she said. 
She said that while the woman had been hit "right outside Starbucks", it was unclear if the debris had fallen from the coffee shop or from a nearby building. 
"I don't think anyone else was hurt. It was a big piece about the size of a coffee table but I think it just hit her," Mrs Davis said. 
A West Midlands Ambulance Service spokesman said: “On arrival, crews found a woman who had suffered very serious head injuries. 
"Sadly, it quickly became apparent that there was nothing that could be done to save her and she was confirmed dead at the scene.” Read More What to do if your flight or train is cancelled because of Storm Doris - Your rights and how to check if your journey is affected Emergency services can be seen on the scene (Photo: Caters News Agency) 
The woman's identity or her age are not yet known with police in the process of contacting her next of kin.Local resident Alexander Bushell, 44, said the falling debris looked "pretty heavy". 
"She wouldn't have stood a chance," he said. 
A spokesman for Starbucks said: "We are shocked and saddened by this terrible incident. We are supporting the police with their investigation and our store will remain closed until further notice." 
In Whitechapel, east London, a woman was injured after an advertising hoarding fell injuring her head. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
